RETA 6077: ROAD SAFETY IN THE ASSOCIATION OF  
SOUTHEAST ASIAN NATIONS 
 
MAJOR CHANGE IN SCOPE AND IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 
 
 
1.  The regional technical assistance (TA) grant was approved in December 2002 for 
$555,000,  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  providing  $500,000,  and  the 
Government of Singapore cofinancing $55,000 equivalent. The purpose of the grant is to 
develop institutional capacity in relevant agencies in the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN) to enable them to effectively address road safety issues. The main 
components and outputs focus on (i)  institutional  strengthening  to  establish  improved 
management structures and effective coordination and funding mechanisms; (ii) capacity 
building and human resource development to upgrade knowledge and skills of key 
agencies  and  staff;  (iii)  regional  cooperation  to  share  knowledge,  disseminate  best 
practices  and  develop  a  knowledge  network;  and  (iv)  encouragement  of  effective 
involvement of the private sector and civil society in road safety activities.  
 
2.  Implementation of the TA commenced in July 2003. The proposed work program 
was discussed at an ASEAN Land Transport Working Group meeting held in Hanoi, Viet 
Nam in August 2003, which agreed on the individual work programs for each country. 
Local consultants had been fielded for all countries, except Malaysia and Myanmar, by 
the end of December 2003, and the program for national road safety workshops and 
action plan sessions has commenced. Agreement has also been reached to hold the 
regional road safety workshop in May 2004, and Malaysia has agreed to host the event. 
The final outputs of the TA will be presented to the ASEAN transport ministers' meeting 
scheduled for October 2004 in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  
 
3.  The Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) approached 
ADB in March 2003, indicating interest in supporting the TA. In September 2003 Sida 
fielded  a  mission  to  discuss  the  regional  traffic  safety  network  that  Sida  recently 
completed in southern Africa and to ascertain the network's applicability in the ASEAN 
region. With some changes to suit ASEAN conditions, the use of the e-learning tool will 
provide  a  superior  basis  for  developing  a  road  safety  network  between  centers  of 
excellence in ASEAN as well as between road safety agencies, the private sector, and 
nongovernment organizations. The information technology platform is easily accessed 
via the Internet, and the information database and distance education courses can be 
adapted to ASEAN conditions. Through use of the technology an ASEAN road safety 
network will be developed to extend road safety knowledge and training throughout the 
region.  
 
4.  Agreement has been reached with Sida to provide supplementary cofinancing of 
SKr2.25 million, approximately $304,000 equivalent, to support the TA. Funds will be 
provided on an untied basis, used in accordance with the ADB Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and ADB Guidelines for Procurement, and a 5% administration fee will be 
imposed.   
 
5.  The President approved on 22 March 2004 the change in scope of the TA, ADB 
administering the supplementary funds financed on a grant basis by the Government of 
Sweden, and direct selection of the University of Linkoping and retroactive financing of 
their services from 3 November 2003.
